DOC.HEAD: Communist Premier Urges Election of Havel As President
EDS: LEADS with 15 grafs to UPDATE with additional Calfa comments, support for Havel, details of meeting. Pickup 14th graf, `Meanwhile, opposition...
DOC.TEXT: The Communist premier today urged the Communist-dominated Parliament to elect opposition leader Vaclav Havel for president by the end of the year. ``It is the government's opinion that there is no alternative ... than to elect Vaclav Havel as president,'' Premier Marian Calfa told deputies in the Federal Assembly. They applauded the recommendation. Thousands of students gathered early today around the statue of St. Wenceslas with banners, balloons and red, white and blue Czechoslovak flags for pro-Havel demonstrations. Some students, who arrived early on trains and buses from throughout the country, passed the time before the demonstrations by Christmas shopping along Wenceslas Square. Calfa's recommendation and its reception by the deputies appeared to signal the final victory of the peaceful revolution, which in one month has swept away 41 years of Communist domination of Czechoslovakia's government. The pro-democracy opposition has negotiated a new non-Communist government that includes two former dissidents; ousted hard-line Communist President Gustav Husak; and introduced reforms in every political, social and religious sphere. Support has been snowballing for Havel, who would be the first non-Communist to hold the office in 41 years. Husak resigned Dec. 10. Havel's only rivals are former Communist Premier Ladislav Adamec and Alexander Dubcek, who led the reforms of the ``Prague Spring'' in 1968 and was removed by the Kremlin. Dubcek, who enjoys tremendous support in his native Slovakia, has been waffling on whether he is in the race. Cestmir Cisar, the students' candidate for president in 1968 and an unofficial contender in the current race, withdrew Monday night and threw his support behind Havel. Czechoslovakia's constitution requires Parliament to elect a new president within two weeks of a vacancy occurring, but Communist and opposition leaders agreed to introduce a resolution to extend the deadline. The two-point agenda approved at the start of today's meeting would give them until late January to choose a president. It was unclear when a vote on the extension would be taken. Calfa said a president should be chosen before the year ends in 12 days. ``The government is making efforts to solve the political and constitutional crisis,'' Calfa said. ``We want to ask the Federal Assembly to contribute to this effort by electing the president by the end of this year.'' Josef Bartoncik, head of the lower house of the bicameral Parliament and leader of the People's Party, said his party would support Havel and would recommend that Parliament recovene Dec. 28 or Dec. 29 to elect the president. The Socialist Party, one of four small parties in the Communist-dominated Parliament, also endorsed Havel. Deputies also were considering the government's reform program, which outlines political and economic changes, repudiates the repression that followed the 1968 anti-reform crackdown, and supports a democratic socialism. Meanwhile, opposition leaders said reports of a planned military coup were spread to cause uncertainty. Opposition member Sasha Vondra was quoted as saying in the Svobodne Slovo daily that the rumor of an impending coup ``is purposefully propagated disinformation and rumor.'' Representatives from the Civic Forum met Monday with Defense Minister Miroslav Vacek who assured them the army supported democratic reform, he said. Col. Stanislav Pohoral, a Defense Ministry spokesman, condemned the circulation of ``leaflets, mainly in Brno, which say a ... military coup is being planned,'' calling it ``totally irresponsible.'' The army leadership ``distances itself from these actions and rejects the accusations,'' he said.
